results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows various visitations to South Western Victoria stretching from Cape Otway to Geelong.

The film begins in Apollo Bay and continues with visits to the Barham River, Cape Otway, Mariner’s lookout and lighthouse, Geelong, Carisbrook Falls and Great Ocean Road with the Twelve Apostles.

The film includes many scenic views of the sea, beaches, mountains and forests. There are several scenes with groups cooking food outdoors and eating throughout.

Of interest is the fashion of the time including men and women’s bathers (swimwear) and the wooden body boards and kayaks used.

Also seen is the T&I mutual Life Society clock tower in Geelong with the famous Father and Son figurine bell ringers coming out to ring the bell.

The film finishes with a scene showing the result of rough seas with capsized boats and debris.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 Apollo Bay shopping strip with old vintage cars
00:01:55:00 horseman, cattle and dogs on the hills
00:03:48:00 Cape Otway Lighthouse and sea views
00:06:59:00 group playing beach cricket
00:08:23:00 Eastern Beach in Geelong followed by Geelong street scenes
00:09:56:00 Johnstone Park next to Geelong Library and Arts Centre
00:10:56:00 Joclyn Penington and older sister with old wooden kayak on the beach
00:11:01:00 Dr Penington in vintage swimming trunks carrying kayak on his shoulder
00:11:19:00 Penington girls in vintage bathers with friend sunbathing and playing around at Eastern Beach, Geelong
0:12:18:00 St Mary’s Church, Geelong
00:13:12:00 Geelong City Hall and former Geelong Post Office and Johnstone Park Pavilion
00:14:01:00 T&G Mutual Life Society clock tower building with close up of the father and son figures coming out of the tower to ring the bell
00:14:31:00 body boarding in Geelong on wooden boards
00:15:24:00 fantail on a barb wired fence
00:19:37:00 group getting their photo taken
00:22:26:00 rough seas with capsized boats and debris at the port

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

Travelling between Port Campbell in Victoria and South Australia’s Port McDonnell, this film follows the Penington family’s trip along the West Victorian coastline.

Included are the Port Campbell cliffs, Great Ocean Road’s ‘The Blow Hole’, ‘Loch Ard Gorge’ and ‘London Bridge’ (now known as the London Arch and the Twelve Apostles).

Other places visited include Warrnambool, Port Fairy, Portland, Mt Gambier, Port McDonnell (SA) and Cape Nelson.

The film shows a number of vehicles from the 1950s and fashion from the time; however, the majority of the film is scenery.

Buildings of interest include the Fletcher Jones Plus 8 building and Gardens in Warrnambool, ‘Hotel Richmond, The original home of the Henty’s’ and Custom House, Port McDonnell.

The film finishes with a semi-fade to black shot of the back of the Penington family caravan and title card ‘The End’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 Port Campbell, sea cliffs, Sherbrook River and the Twelve apostles
00:06:13:00 Warrnambool Welcome Sign
00:07:56:00 FJ Plus 8 industries - Fletcher Jones Garden, Warrnambool
00:09:49:00 Margaret and Ray Penington on the Rocks looking out to sea, Port Fairy
00:12:20:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington on the docks, Portland
00:12:41:00 long shot looking along Henty Street out to sea with the All Saints Catholic Church in view and old 50s cars can be seen driving along it
00:13:03:00 Pennington girls greeting each other on either side of the south Australian Border Sign
00:13:56:00 scenes of Brown, Valley and Blue Lakes, Mt Gambier
00:16:35:00 rook wall and Lookout (Built in 1918), Mt Gambier
00:19:51:00 scenes of the Penington women walking through Cape Nelson Park

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film is set at the Grampians, Victoria. It begins at Halls Gap Caravan park and then continues with highlights of the Grampians including Coronation Chair, Ladies Hat, The Jaws of Death and The Pinnacle.

Each scene has been meticulously titled to indicate the whereabouts within the Grampians.

There is a scene of the original shopping strip and Taylor’s Store and Café and a few old cars of the era and earlier can be seen.

Towards the end of the film is a number of beautiful images of fauna and flora of the area including the Golden Wattle and Banksia.

At one point you can see the Penington girls practising dissection of a rabbit and a scene of them riding horses.

The film ends with the title “And so Home”.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:53:00 Taylor’s Store and Café, Main street, Halls Gap showing old Vintage cars
00:02:32:00 the three Penington girls washing up and doing a rabbit dissection
00:03:23:00 Penington Family sitting in the trees reading
00:05:02:00 Penington family on Mount Victory and the views from the rock
00:05:31:00 Jaws of Death, Grampians
00:06:19:00 Coronation Chair
00:08:31:00 eldest Penington daughter trying to do a flying pose in front of McKenzie falls
00:10:28:00 scenes of rock formation, Grand Canyon
00:12:30:00 Ladies Hat. rock formation
00:14:28:00 flora and fauna from the Grampian area
00:20:07:00 eldest Penington girls holding dead rabbits

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film shows the Penington family visiting several animal sanctuaries in Victoria, Australia. The film is a good example of animal captivity and fashions of the 1940s.

The film begins at Melbourne Zoo with the zoo entrance (built in 1939). The famous elephant Queenie who gave rides for over 40 years is shown. This would have been shortly before she killed her trainer by accident in 1943 leading to her being put down.

There are a number of scenes with the three Penington girls, Margaret, Viviene and Jocelyn, feeding animals. Scenes of monkeys and wallabies amongst other animals are also shown.

The film then moves to Balwyn Wildlife sanctuary with scenes of a monkey circus, pony and dog show. A baboon in clothes doing tricks appears to be the main attraction.

The film then moves to Badger Creek Sanctuary (later called Healesville sanctuary) where platypuses, emus, eagles and koalas are seen.

The film finishes with seals playing in their enclosure.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 Melbourne Zoo Entrance
00:00:17:00 Mrs Penington, Margaret, Viviene and Jocelyn walking along garden path at the zoo. Mrs Penington is pushing an old fashioned stroller.
00:00:25:00 Penington girls feeding a number of different animals, riding Queenie the elephant and on the Merry-go-round
00:04:59:00 animals being directed to perform tricks by man with a stick including monkeys, dogs and monkeys riding ponies
00:06:08:00 TITLE: “Wild Life – Balwyn.” followed by numerous animals of the Sanctuary
00:07:12:00 monkey circus
00:08:21:00 baboon in clothes rocking in a rocking chair and rides a bike
00:09:17:00 lyrebird foraging in the forest with sparrows, Badger Creek Sanctuary
00:10:18:00 koala with baby eating in a eucalyptus tree
00:10:54:00 platypuses being hand fed in enclosure
00:12:12:00 seals in enclosure playing

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film shows an amateur game fishing trip that appears to take place in Bermagui. We see images of the pier with people boarding the small boats and preparing for the fishing trip. Once they set sail, we see seals on the rocks and dolphins swimming alongside the boat. The fishing expedition is a great success. A 250lb marlin is caught and brought on board. The catch of the day is taken back to the pier and admired by impressed onlookers. It is weighed, hung from a wooden scaffold, and put on public display. The flank of the fish is tattooed with the name of the fisherman, (R. Michaels), the marlin’s weight and the date of the catch – 6 February 1938. Various locals stop by and pose with the fish to have their photos taken. In the background are vintage cars and a Shell petrol pump alongside a general store which offers hardware, motor accessories and fishing tackle.

This film shows fashion, cars, buildings and amateur fishing boats. It is a snapshot of game fishing and all that it entails in Bermagui.

Selected Highlights List (timecodes from Access Overscan)

00:01:00:00 fishing boats moored at a pier in what could be Bermagui; people board the boats in readiness for a fishing trip
00:08:00:00 people standing and walking along the pier; good details of the boats
00:25:00:00 two men organise equipment and provisions on the boat
00:48:00:00 a man is seen shooting film footage from a passing boat called Marlin
00:03:17:00 Orion passenger liner sails past the fishing boat
00:03:32:00 game fishing from boat, a marlin is hooked on the line and reeled in
00:03:43:00 fisherman reeling in the marlin
00:04:13:00 marlin is reeled in to the side of the boat and thrashes around in the water
00:04:24:00 the marlin is pulled on to the deck
00:05:33:00 the fishing boat arrives back at the pier

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Sheldon and Sally Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film depicts scenes of Bali and Java taken while on a holiday in 1939. The film is divided into sections indicated by titles: ‘Native Law Court –The Ceiling is Decorated with Pictures of Punishments’; ‘A Balinese Beauty’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – The Procession’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – at the Temple’; ‘Polishing Rice’; ‘Cockfighting is a Popular Past time’; ‘Java’; ‘Java – Selecta-A Hill station above Soerabaja’; ‘Java Semarang’; ‘The Borobudur’; ‘A Mohammedan Funeral at Djockjakarta’; ‘Buitenzorg – Government House and the Botanical Gardens’.

This film is interesting for the Balinese and Javanese street, local transport and people scenes. Images of the architecture, temples, cultural traditions and ceremonies are also a highlight. The film shows pottery techniques and a pottery ware market. There is footage of a funeral procession and a traditional Balinese temple festival or Odalan. The film shows elaborate offerings of fruit and food which is brought with great ceremony by the locals to the temple. We see Borobudur and surrounds, including details of the temple walls and structure. Dutch spelling and place names, as well as images of the hill station resort Selecta, reflect Indonesia’s colonial history and provide context for the time in which the film was made.

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film is titled’ Eastern Tour 1939’ and begins with footage of a passenger liner departing from Sydney Harbour farewelled by waving onlookers and streamers. We see Sydney Harbour and images of the Whitsundays along the way. The highlight of this film is the footage of Bali in 1939. We see Balinese people in a traditional canoe, juking or cadik, paddle alongside the ship as it arrives in Bali. Once on land, there are images of temples, rice terraces, farmers, and a Balinese market with traders plying their trade. There are local people buying food from the stallholders and busying themselves around the market and socialising. We witness a Balinese wedding ceremony and a Gamelan orchestra accompanying a performance of the Legong Dance. The film also shows dancers preparing and dressing for a Djanger Dance Performance, and a Kris dance is performed by men and children on a dirt road in Bali.

results.title: [Orsola: Teramo, 1960]
results.brief_description:
In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico Ciabarra, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine. The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia. The children that appear in the final sequence are related to the filmmaker.

Note: An excerpt from ‘Orsola: Teramo, 1960’ appears in ‘Innamorati’ (2001/3); a four minute digital storytelling work created by Roberta Ciabarra, ACMI Film Programer and daughter of Orsola and Ulderico, as part of a pilot workshop conducted at ACMI in 2001.For technical reasons a re-record of the narration was done in 2003.

Donor has requested that any de-accessioning of the 8mm film that it be returned to him or the family. File Note with Governance.
results.description:
A ‘day in the life’ of a young woman whose fiancé has emigrated to Melbourne, Australia. In the course of a day, Orsola writes her fiancé, Ulderico, a letter, goes out to post it and reads a magazine in the sunshine.

The filmmaker, Francesco Di Silvano, was a family acquaintance and cinema enthusiast who proposed the film as a gift Orsola could send her fiancé, recently settled in Melbourne, Australia.

The related work “Innamorati” - made by Orsola’s daughter - tells the moving story of Orsola’s marriage and her journey to Australia to be reunited with her husband.

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 31]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This short film shows the family swimming and boating.

Selected highlghts list:
00:00:02:00 family members swimming in the shallows of a river among logs
00:00:50:00 boats moored in a sheltered spot including the ‘Shenandoah’ which the family is boarding

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

A selection of family moments, including the departure of an Ansett-ANA plane, possibly at Essendon Airport, and a visit to what may be the Bulleen Pony Club.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 people boarding an Ansett-ANA plane, model V832 Deluxe, followed by its departure across the tarmac
00:00:49:00 family members in the countryside, probably the Bulleen Pony Club, observing two horses in a field, a mare and a foal
00:01:25:00 man and boy feed horse over the fence
00:01:42:00 a toddler dressed in a white pleated skirt and pale pink cardigan playing on front porch of a brick house
